Phtheirospermum japonicum attaches to the roots of its host plants, often grasses and other herbaceous species, using specialized structures called haustoria. These structures penetrate the host's root system, allowing the parasite to extract resources from the host plant.

The seeds of Phtheirospermum japonicum require specific germination cues, such as the presence of host plant-derived chemical signals, to initiate their development. This adaptation ensures the parasite's survival by targeting suitable host plants.

As a parasitic species, Phtheirospermum japonicum can have both ecological and economic impacts, as it can compete with and potentially harm the growth of its host plants, which may include agricultural crops.
